newsitem.title: USA: Dow ends off, renewed inflation fears hit bonds.
newsitem.headline: Dow ends off, renewed inflation fears hit bonds.

text.p: U.S. blue chips ended slightly lower on profit-taking after a two-day rally, pressured by a bond market selloff that was triggered by a Fed governor's inflation warning.

"The bond market is clearly on the weak side and the stock market is struggling," said Marshall Acuff of Smith Barney. He thinks recent strength was overdone prior to the profit warnings rush. "I think investors will be reminded daily of the mortality of portfolios with negative preannouncements."
The Dow industrials fell seven to about 5727.
The Dow surged 127 points over past two sessions as Friday's Augyst payrolls report allayed Wall Street's worst inflation fears.
Broader market measures nudged higher, with the Nasdaq Composite up one to 1149 and the S&P 500 index barely stronger at about 664.
NYSE winners and losers were about even as volume picked up from the sluggish summer pace to about 371 million shares.
Technicians were encouraged by the tape action given stiff selling in bonds. The long bond lost 1/2 point, boosting its yield to 7.11 percent.

Bonds headed south after Fed Gov. Janet Yellen told Reuters, "We're in an inflationary danger zone. ... There's definitely a chance inflation will rise." She stressed that there were uncertainties regarding the economy and that the outlook for inflation and growth were not completely clear.
Her cautious comments suggested she might be willing to support a small, quarter percentage point rise in interest rates at the Fed's next policy-making meeting Sept. 24.
Stocks "have rallied in the past two days. So far this first day of a pullback looks awfully good given what's happening to bonds," said Ralph Bloch of Raymond James.

Bloch, Raymond James' chief technical analyst, did not see a steep stock selloff in the near-term. "Usually, you don't have a big chop on the downside with readings like this on breadth and the leading group -- technology. Any pullback will be shallow and short-lived."
He was encouraged by Tuesday's NYSE volume pickup. "I've been saying that if this market has any chance of getting legs, volume better pick up."
"We have the Beige Book tomorrow, producer prices Thursday and consumer prices Friday. If the numbers are benign I think this market goes higher," Bloch said.

The Philadelphia Stock Exchange's semiconductor index rose fractionally to 161.65 ahead of a key industry barometer. The August book-to-bill report, due later today, is expected to be between 0.86 and 0.92, up from July's 0.85. The report measures new orders for computer chips against shipments.
Leading chip maker Intel rose 13/16 to 84-5/16.
Analysts said tech stocks would get an added boost if the book-to-bill comes in on-target or unexpectedly stronger.
Topping the NYSE actives list was ITT Corp, which lost 14 percent or 7-7/8 points to 48-1/8. It warned quarterly results will be below forecasts because of gaming revenue shortfalls.
Bear Stearns, Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette and Smith Barney downgraded their ratings on ITT.

Ford Motor Co lost 3/8 to 31-5/8, pulling off a 30-1/8 session low, after forecasting its second-half loss in Latin America will be roughly twice as large as its first-half loss of $130 million in the region. Brazil makes up the largest portion of Ford's Latin American operations.

Shares of General Motors Corp, which also has substantial Brazilian operations, lost 3/8 to 47-7/8. Chrysler Corp, which recently announced a $315 million plan for its first Brazilian assembly plant, was off 1/2 to 28-1/4.
Gap Inc added 1-1/4 to 31-5/8. Goldman Sachs upgraded Gap to the firm's priority list from its recommended list.

International Business Machines Corp rose 1/2 to 118-1/8 after IBM said strong customer demand for its new models of mainframe computers has been so strong that it may sell out all it can make this year.

Praegitzer Industries Inc, a circuit board maker, tumbled 26 percent or 3-8/16 to 9-13/16 after warning first-quarter earnings would fall short of expectations. It cited product mix changes and higher-than-expected expenses related to the integration of its acquisition of Trend Circuits Inc.
The Nasdaq Composite rose 0.72 to 1149.43.
The S&P 500 index rose 0.05 to 663.81.
(Figures official as of 1645 EDT/2045 GMT)
-- Wall Street desk, 212 859 1721
